The Act titled "TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005" allows for the advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 authorizes the advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006, extending activities through December 31, 2005. The TANF Emergency Response and Recovery Act of 2005 allows advance payment of TANF block grants for the first quarter of fiscal year 2006, extending activities through December 31, 2005. Amendments include changes to deadlines and funding allocations in the Social Security Act. Extension of the National Random Sample Study of Child Welfare and Child Welfare Waiver Authority through December 31, 2005, with appropriations as necessary. Grants and payments authorized until the first quarter of fiscal year 2006 at the same level as the first quarter of fiscal year 2005. Reimbursement of states for TANF benefits provided to assist families affected by Hurricane Katrina. Beginning with the enactment of this Act until August 31, 2006, a State qualifies as a needy State under the Social Security Act if it has provided short-term, nonrecurring cash benefits to families displaced by Hurricane Katrina from another State with a declared disaster area. The State must confirm that the family is not receiving cash benefits from any other State program. The total amount paid to a needy State under the Social Security Act cannot exceed the cash benefits provided to the families. No State match is required for payments made under this section. SEC. 4. Availability of additional TANF funds for hurricane-damaged states. Certain States like Louisiana, Mississippi, and Alabama are eligible for loans under the Social Security Act until the end of fiscal year 2006. The loans made to these states cannot exceed 20 percent of the State family assistance grant for that year. Additionally, these states will not face penalties for failing to repay the loans. The loans cannot exceed 20 percent of the State family assistance grant for that year. Additionally, these states will not face penalties for failing to repay the loans. After the enactment of this Act and before October 1, 2007, no interest payment can be made on such loans. SEC. 5 allows States or tribes to use unspent TANF funds to support needy families affected by Hurricane Katrina without fiscal year limitation. SEC. 6 states that work requirements and time limits under the TANF program are not triggered by families receiving temporary TANF benefits due to the hurricane. Benefits provided under a State program funded under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act to meet a family's subsistence needs resulting from Hurricane Katrina will not be considered assistance for certain purposes. SEC. 7. WAIVER OF TANF PENALTIES IN HURRICANE-DAMAGED STATES.

The Secretary of Health and Human Services will not penalize Louisiana, Mississippi, or Alabama for non-compliance with certain provisions of the Social Security Act related to Hurricane Katrina until the end of fiscal year 2006.
